chapter: Welcome to the CEPEH Data Analysis Site
heading: Acknowledgments
text: work supported ERASMUS+ Strategic Partnership Higher Education “Chatbot Enhance Personalise European Healthcare Curricula (CEPEH)” (www.cepeh.eu) (2019-1-UK01- KA203-062091) project European Union.

heading: Introduction
text:
Personalised Healthcare Education needed meet growing demand quality maintenance.
growing evidence around chatbots, namely machine conversation systems- programs potential change way students learn search information.Chatbots can quiz existing knowledge, enable higher student engagement learning task, support higher-order cognitive activities.
large-scale learning scenarios hight student--lecturer ratio, chatbots can help tackle issue individualized student support facilitate personalised learning.
However, limited examples chatbots European Healthcare Curricula utilised combine continuum cognitive processes presented Bloom’s taxonomy, idea repetitive tasks can done chatbot- provide greater access scale faculty time.Thus, CEPEH strategic partnership co-created open access chatbots utilising artificial intelligence, promoting innovative practices digital era, supporting current curricula fostering open education.CEPEH Erasmus+ strategic partnership aimed co-design implement new pedagogical approaches , particular, chatbots European medical nursing schools.
CEPEH used use participatory design engage stakeholders (students, healthcare workforce staff, lecturers, clinicians, etc.) order co-design effective chatbots release open access resources.
CEPEH, effective use digital technologies open education incorporated healthcare curricula.
enabled students increase health medical related skills flexible learning.CEPEH expected students adopted new digital pedagogy improve skills competences flexible personalised learning, teaching staff enhanced e-learning tool co-creation competences make use co-design best practices recommendations use.
also expected increased cooperation partners.
Thus, long term, CEPEH expects influence development medical nursing curricula digital innovation, foster quality future healthcare workforce improve international competitiveness partners’ healthcare curricula.

financial, stakeholder, time, efficacy benefits.
creation process CEPEH resources significantly different literature, report highlights approach CEPEH team towards enhancing personalised healthcare education can achieved.

heading: 1.1 Participants
text:
dataset 14 males 28 females therefore total 42 participants.

3 females 4 males Cyprus.

heading: 1.4 Materials and Measures
text:
measures used fit within newly developed Chatbot Evaluation Framework- takes best measures 5 previous frameworks.
Denecke Warren ​[2]​ derived several quality dimensions attributes previous chatbot literature.
formed six perspectives review articles mobile health applications.six perspectives : 1) Task-oriented, 2) Artificial intelligence, 3) System quality perspective, 4) Linguistic perspective, 5) UX Perspective, 6) Healthcare quality perspective.capture perspectives, used several validated materials can distinguish elements CEPEH chatbots.

heading: 1.4.1 Chatbot Usability Questionnaire (CUQ)
text:
Chatbot Usability Questionnaire (CUQ) ​[4]​ new questionnaire specifically designed measuring usability chatbots interdisciplinary team Ulster University.
CUQ can used alongside prevalent System Usability Scale Score (SUS) ​[5]​.
Multiple metrics appropriate measuring usability chatbots ​[6]​ therefore combination two scores can provide -inclusive overview.

heading: 1.4.2 UTAUT2 (Unified Theory of Acceptance and Use of Technology)
text:
underpinning theory UTAUT2 four key constructs intentions using technology based resources: 1) performance expectancy, 2) effort expectancy, 3) social influence, 4) enabling conditions.TAM UTAUT2 cross measuring technology acceptance, however UTAUT2 applied probing questions.
studies exist use technology acceptance theories intention use products explicitly incorporate AI.
recent extension UTAUT2 model added five (health, convenience comfort, sustainability, safety, security, personal innovativeness) additional influencing factors accommodate AI [7].
can used products either health, household use, mobility can help explain behavioural intention use behaviour chatbots.

text:

Add numbers find total score, multiply 2.5.
result score 100 can compared determined average score 68.

heading: 1.4.5 Technology Acceptance Model (TAM)
text:
Technology Acceptance Model (TAM) [1] specifically developed primary aim identifying determinants involved computer acceptance general; secondly, examine variety information technology usage behaviours; thirdly, provide parsimonious theoretical explanatory model.
TAM suggests attitude direct predictor intention use technology, turn predict actual usage technology.
modification nine sub-scales questionnaire consists applying items context chatbots.
items, except measuring attitudes, utilize seven-point Likert scale ranging “strongly agree” “strongly disagree” middle neutral point [2].nine sub-scales questionnaire:• Ease use chatbots • Perceived usefulness chatbots • Intention use.
• Attitude toward usage chatbots.
• Perception personal efficacy use chatbot resource.
• Perception external control toward chatbots.

• Intrinsic motivation use chatbot resources.
• Perceived costs chatbots.

heading: 4.1 CEPEH Training Event 2
text:
Pre-Training Event survey May 9th-13th 2022 Thessaloniki, GreeceTwenty-six participants attended Training Event, along approximately 10 staff members. 21 undergraduate students 5 postgraduate students, completed survey total 26 responses. 86% participants stated similar event like training event CEPEH facilitated. 90% students found event schedule organised, 70% agreed planned sessions relevant interest remaining 30% enough experience understand context determine interested training event. 95% students agreeing strongly agreeing training event location great, remaining person leave additional comments.Table 1 suggested attendees minimal intention share ideas due lack previous experience attending events, due lack knowledge area. However, interested listening groups hearing contextual cases healthcare.77% participants stated novices experience chatbots healthcare attending learn . remaining 23% (7 students) stated competent limited experience chatbots healthcare.One day several events regarding cybersecurity healthcare. asked events, 83% stated neutral disagreed felt confident cybersecurity knowledge healthcare. addition, 80% stated neutral disagreed felt strong cybersecurity safety healthcare. Table 2 shows main pre post results suggesting positive experience 75% attendees measures.90% (23) students heard event lecturer professor, CEPEH newsletter (2), 1 person informed anatomy tutoring system Karolinska Institute. Additionally, 60% suggested training event somebody else course started.six individuals stated neutral disagree asked issues registration finding information event. may due dependent emails receive information, instead dedicated website information available anytime.face--face, participants asked sufficient Covid-19 precautions place facility, 94% agreed sufficient precautions, two individuals stated give information additional input box provided.

heading: 4.1.1 Appearance of citations and references section (pandoc)
text:
default, oxforddown lets Pandoc handle citations inserted text references section.
can change appearance citations references specifying CSL (Citation Style Language) file csl metadata field index.Rmd.
default, oxforddown Americal Psychological Association (7th Edition), author-year format.style, number variations citation syntax useful know:Put author names outside parenthesis
: @Shea2014 says blah.
Becomes: Shea et al. (2014) says blah.
: @Shea2014 says blah.Becomes: Shea et al. (2014) says blah.Include citation-year (parenthesis)
: Shea et al. says blah [-@Shea2014]
Becomes: Shea et al. says blah (2014)
: Shea et al. says blah [-@Shea2014]Becomes: Shea et al. says blah (2014)Add text page chapter references citation
: [see @Shea2014, pp. 33-35; also @Wu2016, ch. 1]
Becomes: Blah blah (see Shea et al., 2014, pp. 33–35; also Wu, 2016, ch. 1).
: [see @Shea2014, pp. 33-35; also @Wu2016, ch. 1]Becomes: Blah blah (see Shea et al., 2014, pp. 33–35; also Wu, 2016, ch. 1).want numerical citation style instead, try csl: bibliography/transactions--computer-human-interaction.csl just browse Zotero Style Repository look one like.
convenience, can set line spacing space bibliographic entries reference section directly YAML header index.Rmd.prefer use biblatex natbib handle references, see chapter.

heading: 4.1.2 Insert references easily with RStudio’s Visual Editor
text:
easy way insert citations, use RStudio’s Visual Editor.
Make sure latest version RStudio – visual editor originally really buggy, especially relation references, per v2022.02.0, ’s great!

heading: 4.2 Cross-referencing
text: can make cross-references sections within document, well figures (images plots) tables.general cross-referencing syntax \@ref(label)

heading: 4.2.1 Section references
text: Headers automatically assigned reference label, text lower caps separated dashes. example, # header automatically given label -header. # header can referenced \@ref(-section)Remember wrote section ???can also use hyperlink syntax add # label, though guaranteed work properly HTML output:write Remember wrote [previous section](#citations)?becomes Remember wrote previous section?

heading: 4.2.1.1 Creating custom labels
text:
good idea create custom labels sections. automatically assigned labels change change titles sections - avoid , can create labels leave untouched change section titles.create custom labels adding {#label} header, e.g. # section {#-label}.
See chapter title example. section 3.

heading: 4.2.2 Figure (image and plot) references
text:
refer figures (.e. images plots) use syntax \@ref(fig:label)GOTCHA: Figures tables must captions wish cross-reference .Let’s add image:refer image \@ref(fig:captain).
Figure ?? image.Figure ?? saw cars plot.

heading: 4.2.3 Table references
text:
refer tables use syntax \@ref(tab:label)refer table \@ref(tab:cars-table2).
Table ?? table.Table ?? saw less cars table.

heading: 4.2.4 Including page numbers
text:
Finally, PDF output might also want include page number reference, ’s easy find physical printed output.
LaTeX command , looks like : \pageref{fig/tab:label} (note: curly braces, parentheses)output PDF, can use raw LaTeX directly .Rmd files. wanted include page cars plot write:: Figure \@ref(fig:cars-plot) page \pageref(fig:cars-plot)Becomes: Figure ?? page

heading: 4.2.4.1 Include page numbers only in PDF output
text: problem LaTeX commands don’t display HTML output, gitbook output ’d see simply “Figure ?? page”.One way get around use inline R code insert text, use ifelse statement check output format insert appropriate text.: `r ifelse(knitr::is_latex_output(), "Figure \\@ref(fig:cars-plot) page \\pageref{fig:cars-plot}", "")`Inserts (check PDF gitbook):Note need escape backslash another backslash get correct output.

heading: 4.3 Collaborative writing
text:
Best practices collaboration change tracking using R Markdown still open question.
blog post One year dissertate Lucy D’Agostino, highly recommend, author notes knits .Rmd files word document, uses googledrive R package send Google Drive comments / revisions co-authors, incorporates Google Drive suggestions hand .Rmd source files.
bit clunky, ongoing discussions among R Markdown developers best way handle collaborative writing (see issue #1463 GitHub, CriticMarkup among suggestions).now, open question community R Markdown users.
often knit format can easily imported Google Docs comments, go suggested revisions manually incorporate back .Rmd source files.

chapter: 6 Text Mining, Natural Language Processing, and Sentiment Analysis
heading: 6.3.1 3.1 Find most frequent words
text:
Easily find frequent words using count()Data must tidy format (one token per line)sort = TRUE show frequent words firsttidy_books %>%
count(word, sort = TRUE)preparation words use understanding frequencies, emotional valence compared. table word ‘helpful’ positive connotation, however 386 words, many several occurrences.sentiment participants? types emotional words used?
code:
library(tidytext)
library(tidyverse)
library(tm)
library(tigerstats)
library(tidyselect)

CEPEHQ_freq <- CEPEHQ_tidy %>% group_by(doc_id) %>% count(word, sort=TRUE)

CEPEHQ_freq <- CEPEHQ_freq[-6,]

CEPEHQ_freq## # A tibble: 386 × 3

```r # install.packages(pdftools) # split PDF into pages stored in figures/sample-content/pdf_embed_example/split/ # pdftools::pdf_split("figures/sample-content/pdf_embed_example/Lyngs2020_FB.pdf", # output = "figures/sample-content/pdf_embed_example/split/") # grab the pages pages <- list.files("figures/sample-content/pdf_embed_example/split", full.names = TRUE) # set how wide you want the inserted PDFs to be: # 1.0 is 100 per cent of the oxforddown PDF page width; # you may want to make it a bit bigger pdf_width <- 1.2 # for each PDF page, insert it nicely and # end with a page break cat(stringr::str_c("\\newpage \\begin{center} \\makebox[\\linewidth][c]{\\includegraphics[width=", pdf_width, "\\linewidth]{", pages, "}} \\end{center}"))
